newsitem.title: USA: Arco says considers disposal of coal assets.
newsitem.headline: Arco says considers disposal of coal assets.

text.p: Atlantic Richfield Co (ARCO) Tuesday said it would consider withdrawing from its worldwide coal business after disposing of U.S. and Australian coal mining operations.
ARCO's U.S. coal mining operations, the nation's fourth-largest, will be formed into a stand alone company and possibly spun-off to shareholders.
"At this point there are no buyers being solicited," ARCO spokesman Albert Greenstein told Reuters, adding an advisory committee was being formed to decide a course of action.
ARCO's coal assets totaled $1.75 billion at the end of 1996, out of assets totaling of $25.7 billion, Greenstein said.
In 1996, ARCO's worldwide coal shipments totaled 62.4 million tons, with 51.6 tons mined in the U.S.. Domestic mining operations are located in Wyoming, Colorado and Utah.
"While ARCO has some of the best coal assets in the world, we no longer regard them as part of our core business," said Mike Bowlin, ARCO chairman and chief executive officer in a prepared statement.
ARCO also said it will likely monetize its Australian coal interests through a public offering in the Australian equity markets or an outright sale.
The overall process is expected to take at least six months and could extend into 1998.
Net income from coal operations for 1995 and 1996 was $75 million and $60 million respectively.
ARCO Coal Company employment at year-end 1996 was 2,600, including about 1,000 in Australia.
